Text:
This is a tale of ages past, when Elisabeth still
safeguarded the borders of a small nation as its
ruler.
Mm...mm...
...sabeth. My lady.
Good morning, Lady Elisabeth.
...So it's morning.
Well, almost noon, to be precise.
...Ugh.
Please, do not go back to sleep!
But you know how much I dislike mornings...

Your blood pressure truly is exceptionally low...
Although I suppose that's true for all vampires.
By and large, yes...but in my case particularly so...
Good grief, she's practically asleep again already...

What to do... Wake her up on the wrong side of the
bed and the resulting tantrum could cost us another
mountain...
Say...I do recall...a dream to that effect...

Oh, that was no dream—you actually did that...
Alright, I think I know just what to try this time.
Mary leaves Elisabeth's side.
Mm, peace...at last... Zzz...
A few minutes later—
Good morning, Lady Elisabeth.
Mmm...
Urk! What...is that burning odor!

I've prepared some morning repast for you.
Garlic toast, to be precise.

There is a time and place for everything, and garlic
most certainly is not a bedside alarm!
But you are wide awake now, yes?
Seriously... Is there no better way of doing this?

Then perhaps you should try waking when you're
needed.
*sigh*... I can't find it in me to be angry.

Should I instruct the servants to ready garlic for
you in the morning, my lady?
...I'd rather you didn't.

Furthermore, what if rumors spread that vampires
despise garlic?

If that happens, perhaps we should simply say that it
is only you yourself who can't stomach it.

Then I doubt we would ever catch even whiff of it in
this land ever again. That's how much your subjects
here care for you, my lady.

Such flattery so early in the day... What's gotten
into you?

Heehee, you're meant to make the rounds today, so I
thought I would set the mood.

Well, it kind of defeats the purpose if you reveal
what you're doing, don't you think?

Your official duties don't begin until noon, so
please take this time to get ready and have your
morning meal.

I believe I will. I must say, though...my morning
schedule always seems to be awfully empty.

As much as I would love to fill those hours with
tasks, there's no telling whether you would actually
be awake to perform them.

Yes, yes, spare me the scolding. You've made your
point abundantly clear.

Now then, my first order of business is breakfast.
Then I will see to any paperwork that has
accumulated while I slept.

As you wish, my lady. I shall ready the documents
for your review.
Thank you.
Elisabeth eats her morning meal of garlic toast.
Mm... Delicious...

...I do seem to have caused poor Mary quite a bit of
trouble, however.

I suppose I can make amends for it all when I handle
my afternoon affairs.
And thus begins Elisabeth's day—
